Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as an attempt to silence debate and control information, likened to socialist or communist tactics.
The decision-making power is concentrated in the hands of a few bureaucrats, which is viewed as undemocratic.
The government itself is accused of being a major source of misinformation and disinformation.
The legislation is perceived as an overreach of government power and a threat to free speech.
Fact-checking is criticized as biased and aligned with the highest bidder.
The proposal is seen as a step towards implementing communist rule and stifling free speech.
Notable Quotes: The announcement by the Minister for Communications... is totally and utterly laughable.
Government has without doubt been THE SINGLE BIGGEST perpetrator of fake narratives, misleading information, and disinformation.
Let the people decide what is right and what is wrong – FOR THEMSELVES.
The Minister isn’t seeking to combat misinformation and disinformation – he is seeking to do his part to implement Communist rule.
